doctrines.name: Multilateralism
doctrines.description: Coordinating diplomatic efforts among multiple countries to address international issues.
doctrines.explanation: Effective when building consensus but can be slow and require compromise.

doctrines.name: Isolationism
doctrines.description: Minimizing international involvement and focusing on domestic affairs.
doctrines.explanation: Reduces foreign entanglements but can lead to diplomatic isolation and reduced influence.

doctrines.name: Public Diplomacy
doctrines.description: Engaging directly with foreign populations rather than just governments.
doctrines.explanation: Builds long-term relationships but requires consistent messaging and cultural sensitivity.

doctrines.name: National Interest
doctrines.description: Prioritizing a country's own strategic goals in diplomatic relations.
doctrines.explanation: Provides clear direction but can appear self-serving to international partners.

doctrines.name: Balance of Power
doctrines.description: Maintaining stability by preventing any single nation from becoming too powerful.
doctrines.explanation: Historical approach that can prevent dominance but may lead to arms races.

doctrines.name: Collective Security
doctrines.description: Nations agreeing to defend each other against aggression.
doctrines.explanation: Creates deterrence through unity but requires genuine commitment from all parties.

doctrines.name: Protectionism
doctrines.description: Restricting international trade to protect domestic industries.
doctrines.explanation: May preserve jobs short-term but often leads to economic inefficiency and retaliation.

doctrines.name: Free Trade
doctrines.description: Reducing barriers to international commerce and investment.
doctrines.explanation: Promotes economic growth and interdependence but can create winners and losers domestically.
